headline.main: FATALISM AND FATALITIES IN THE APPALACHIAN MINES

docs.lead_paragraph: Because coal mining is the riskiest of heavy industrial jobs, it has nutured a pervasive fatalism. Death in the pits is part of the monotonous folk lore of mining coal. To this day, the demonstrable fact that mine safety is both variable and controllable is sometimes under appreciated, as much by coal miners as by mine owners. The point was underlined last week in Congressional testimony by investigators of the Federal Mine Safety Enforcement Agency. Appearing before a House Education and Labor subcommittee, convened to investigate the effects of budget cuts and deregulation on mine safety, the investigators cited three recent mine disasters and said that in each case ''lax inspection'' was not solely at fault. In essence the miners had killed themselves and management practices had allowed them to do so, the investigators said.

headline.main: STUDY REAFFIRMS GENERAL DOUBTS OVER MARIJUANA

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A long-awaited report released today by the National Academy of Sciences asserts that marijuana smoking has certain undesirable short-term effects on behavior and the body. But it says reliable evidence is so scanty that it is impossible to draw any firm conclusions about potential long-term health hazards. The report was prepared by a special panel of health authorities formed by the academy's Institute of Medicine. The panel's chairman, Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor of The New England Excerpts from report are on page 9. Journal of Medicine, said that ''what little we know for certain'' is cause for ''serious national concern.''

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM THE FEDERAL REPORT ON MARIJUANA

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Effects on the Nervous System and on Behavior We can say with confidence that marijuana produces acute effects on the brain, including chemical and electrophysiological changes. Its most clearly established acute effects are on mental functions and behavior. With a severity directly related to dose, marijuana impairs motor coordination and affects tracking ability and sensory and perceptual functions important for safe driving and the operation of other machines; it also impairs short-term memory and slows learning. Other acute effects include feelings of euphoria and other mood changes, but there also are disturbing mental phenomena, such as brief periods of anxiety, confusion, or psychosis.

headline.main: SURGEON GENERAL REPORT BROADENS LIST OF CANCERS LINKED TO SMOKING

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In one of the strongest indictments of cigarettes since the landmark Federal report on smoking 18 years ago, the Surgeon General of the United States today broadened the list of cancers linked to cigarette use. He declared smoking ''the most important health issue of our time.'' ''Cigarette smoking is clearly identified as the chief preventable cause of death in our society,'' said the Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop at a press conference, adding that 30 percent of all cancer deaths were attributable to smoking. The report, in addition to discussing the long-known relationship between smoking and cancer of the lung, larynx and esophagus, said that smoking was a factor in bladder, kidney and pancreatic cancers.

headline.main: HIGHLIGHTS OF SURGEON GENERAL'S REPORT ON SMOKING

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are some highlights of the Surgeon General's Report on Smoking: - Smoking will cause about 130,000 deaths from cancer this year. It is the ''major cause'' of cancers of the lung, larynx, oral cavity and esophagus, and a ''contributory factor'' to cancers of the bladder, kidneys and pancreas.
